newsitem.title: UK: Germany should not revalue gold - ex Buba member.
newsitem.headline: Germany should not revalue gold - ex Buba member.

text.p: Germany's Bundesbank should not succumb to government pressure to revalue the country's gold reserves as part of its efforts to meet Europe's economic and monetary union (EMU) criteria, a former Bundesbank council member said Friday.

Speaking at a conference in London, Wilhelm Noelling said revaluing gold reserves was a one-off measure and should not be accepted given the Bundesbank's long-standing insistence on sustainability of fiscal stability required for EMU membership.
"It is now in the hands of the Bundesbank to safeguard the deutschemark -- which is its statutory duty -- even if that means that Germany eventually fails to qualify for EMU entry in 1999," he said.

Noelling, now a professor at Hamburg University, told a presentation organised by Robert Fleming Securities that revaluing gold and the central bank's other reserves could be in Germany's national interest.
The proceeds should be used to finance employment and productivity rather than reduce debt and plug holes in the country's public-sector budget, he said.
German Finance Minister Theo Waigel announced last week plans to change the conservative valuation of Germany's gold reserves to closer to prevailing market values.
